member.name: T:Eamon.Framework.DataStorage.Generic.IDbTable`1
member.summary: Represents a collection of records of type T in a database.
member.typeparam: The interface type of the records.
member.remarks: This defines the concept of a database table in Eamon CS. It is integral to the storage of all game-related records (rooms, artifacts, monsters, etc), both in memory and in filesystem. The interface exposes a set of IDbTables, one for each record type derived from . The database table class heirarchy is derived from the abstract class . If you look inside the various game .XML files you will see that they consist of the serialized concretes of IDbTable mentioned below in the See Also section.

member.name: P:Eamon.Framework.DataStorage.Generic.IDbTable`1.Records
member.summary: This is the collection of records stored in the database table.
member.remarks: The records stored here are keyed using their Uid property, which as the name implies is expected to be unique. Records can be added, removed or modified dynamically at runtime as needed. If you look in the various .XML game files you will see that you can actually store records of type T, or any derivative of T. This is why, for example, if you look in MONSTERS.XML for "Test Adventure" and "A Runcible Cargo" you will see records of type and , respectively. This polymorphic behavior is at the heart of custom adventure development in Eamon CS.

member.name: P:Eamon.Framework.DataStorage.Generic.IDbTable`1.FreeUids
member.summary: A collection of Uids available for reuse by new instances of this record type; may be empty.
member.remarks: This property is intended to be used in conjunction with and . As a general rule you should rely on these methods to manipulate the FreeUids list.

member.name: P:Eamon.Framework.DataStorage.Generic.IDbTable`1.Cache
member.summary: A quick-lookup cache of records stored in most recently used (MRU) order.
member.remarks: This cache contains the records of type T most recently used by the system. The collection is currently implemented as a B-Plus Tree, but lookups amount to full table scans so the cache is always checked first. The size of the cache is set by and old records will fall out as new records are added.

member.name: P:Eamon.Framework.DataStorage.Generic.IDbTable`1.CurrUid
member.summary: A sequence number used to store the last unique ID allocated to a record of type T.
member.remarks: Each record type gets its own sequence number to draw Uids from. Uids start at one (1), and zero (0) is considered null or invalid. The and methods should be used to manage all Uid allocations and deallocations, respectively. When a Uid is freed, either CurrUid is decremented (when Uid equals CurrUid), or the Uid is added to for later reuse.

member.name: M:Eamon.Framework.DataStorage.Generic.IDbTable`1.FreeRecords(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Fully reinitializes the IDbTable and restores it to its initial (empty) state.
member.param: Optionally call Dispose method on every freed record.
member.remarks: This method clears out anything stored in , optionally calling Dispose on every record freed. It also clears the and , and resets to zero (0). The empty IDbTable is ready to be reused.
member.returns: Success

member.name: M:Eamon.Framework.DataStorage.Generic.IDbTable`1.GetRecordsCount
member.summary: Gets the number of records of type T stored in the Records collection.

member.name: M:Eamon.Framework.DataStorage.Generic.IDbTable`1.FindRecord(System.Int64)
member.summary: Gets a record from the Records collection.
member.param: The Uid of the record to find.
member.remarks: This method finds and returns a record of type T with the given Uid. If the record is not found, the method returns null. The search begins in the and on failure, is searched. Any record found is either moved or added to the head of the Cache; on overflow, the least recently used (LRU) record will be ejected.
member.returns: The record with the given Uid or null if not found.

member.name: M:Eamon.Framework.DataStorage.Generic.IDbTable`1.FindRecord(System.Type,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets a record from the Records collection based on interface type.
member.param: Optionally try to find a record directly implementing the interface.
member.remarks: This method finds and returns the first record of type T that matches the provided interface type. If the record directly implements the interface, it will always match. If the interface is an ancestor then exactMatch must be false for a match to occur. or an ancestor.
member.returns: The first record matching the provided interface type or null if not found.

member.name: M:Eamon.Framework.DataStorage.Generic.IDbTable`1.AddRecord(`0,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Adds a record to the Records collection.
member.param: Optionally clone the record and add the clone instead.
member.remarks: This method adds a record of type T to . It is assumed the record has been properly initialized and its Uid has been assigned. If a record with the same Uid already exists in the collection the attempt to add the new one will fail. You can optionally choose to do a deep clone of the record and add the clone instead if you would prefer.
member.returns: Success, InvalidArg, AlreadyExists, OutOfMemory

member.name: M:Eamon.Framework.DataStorage.Generic.IDbTable`1.RemoveRecord(System.Int64)
member.summary: Removes a record from the Records collection.
member.param: The Uid of the record to remove.
member.remarks: This method removes a record of type T with the given Uid from and (if necessary) and returns it. If the record is not found, the method returns null. If the record is no longer needed and its IsUidRecycled property is true, you should call Dispose on the record to ensure the Uid is freed; otherwise you must do this manually using .
member.returns: The record with the given Uid or null if not found.

member.name: M:Eamon.Framework.DataStorage.Generic.IDbTable`1.RemoveRecord(System.Type,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Removes a record from the Records collection based on interface type.
member.param: Optionally try to find a record directly implementing the interface.
member.remarks: This method removes the first record of type T that matches the provided interface type from both and (if necessary) . The record, if found, is returned; otherwise null is returned. Take a look at the comments for and because they also apply to this method.
member.returns: The first record matching the provided interface type or null if not found.

member.name: M:Eamon.Framework.DataStorage.Generic.IDbTable`1.GetRecordUid(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets the next available record Uid.
member.param: Optionally allocate the Uid for use (this is the default).
member.remarks: This method manages the allocation of Uids for records of type T. If the allocate parameter is true, then a Uid will be allocated; otherwise, it simply returns the value of , the most recently allocated Uid. During allocation, if the list is not empty, the head of the list is removed and returned. Otherwise, the CurrUid is incremented and returned. Records that have Uids allocated by this method should always set IsUidRecycled to true. Then either the record's Dispose method or can be called (but not both) to free the Uid so it can later be reused.
member.returns: Either the next allocated Uid or most recently allocated Uid; else returns -1 on failure.

member.name: M:Eamon.Framework.DataStorage.Generic.IDbTable`1.FreeRecordUid(System.Int64)
member.summary: Frees a record Uid, making it available again for use.
member.remarks: This method is used to free a Uid allocated to a record of type T, making it available again for use. You should always free any Uid allocated with , either indirectly using the record's Dispose method or directly using FreeRecordUid (but never both). When the Uid is equal to , the latter is simply decremented; otherwise it is added to the tail of the list. Due to the minimal validation done on the passed in Uid, it is the caller's responsibility to ensure it is valid.

member.name: T:Eamon.Framework.Delegates
member.summary: A collection of C# delegate signatures.
member.remarks: These delegates are used by to support player command parsing, direct object and indirect object resolution. There are methods that match these signatures in and that the parser uses as default implementations; these are detailed below.

member.name: T:Eamon.Framework.Delegates.GetArtifactListFunc
member.summary: Queries the game database for a list of artifacts matching a criteria set.
member.param: The should query function; this is evaluated before proceeding with the main query. If it returns true, the main query proceeds; if false, the main query never happens and an empty list is returned. Typically this will be a simple lambda like () => true, but it can vary based on the given circumstances (eg, maybe the room is dark).

The set of methods used to match artifacts in the game database. Each method is used as a query Where clause and the resulting artifacts are added to the list. This means the database is queried once for each member of the set. Note that depending on the methods it is possible for the same artifact to show up in the list more than once.
member.returns: A list of artifacts matching the given criteria set. At minimum an empty list should be returned (never null).

member.name: T:Eamon.Framework.Delegates.GetMonsterListFunc
member.summary: Queries the game database for a list of monsters matching a criteria set.
member.param: The should query function; this is evaluated before proceeding with the main query. If it returns true, the main query proceeds; if false, the main query never happens and an empty list is returned. Typically this will be a simple lambda like () => true, but it can vary based on the given circumstances (eg, maybe the room is dark).

The set of methods used to match monsters in the game database. Each method is used as a query Where clause and the resulting monsters are added to the list. This means the database is queried once for each member of the set. Note that depending on the methods it is possible for the same monster to show up in the list more than once.
member.returns: A list of monsters matching the given criteria set. At minimum an empty list should be returned (never null).

member.name: T:Eamon.Framework.Delegates.FilterArtifactListFunc
member.summary: Filters a given artifact list, returning all records matching a given name.
member.param: The list of artifacts to filter.
member.remarks: The passed in artifact list may be searched using a variety of techniques, including direct artifact name match, plural name match and synonym match. These techniques may be augmented with partial matching (that is, start or end of string) if all else fails. The passed in artifact list will not be altered and the returned list can contain multiple artifacts.
member.returns: A list of artifacts matching the given name. At minimum an empty list should be returned (never null).

member.name: T:Eamon.Framework.Delegates.FilterMonsterListFunc
member.summary: Filters a given monster list, returning all records matching a given name.
member.param: The list of monsters to filter.
member.remarks: The passed in monster list may be searched using a variety of techniques, including direct monster name match, plural name match and synonym match. These techniques may be augmented with partial matching (that is, start or end of string) if all else fails. The passed in monster list will not be altered and the returned list can contain multiple monsters.
member.returns: A list of monsters matching the given name. At minimum an empty list should be returned (never null).

member.name: T:Eamon.Framework.Delegates.FilterRecordListFunc
member.summary: Filters a given record list, returning all records matching a given name.
member.param: The list of records to filter. These records can be artifacts, monsters or both.
member.remarks: The passed in record list may be searched using a variety of techniques, including direct record name match, plural name match and synonym match. These techniques may be augmented with partial matching (that is, start or end of string) if all else fails. The passed in record list will not be altered and the returned list can contain multiple records.
member.returns: A list of records matching the given name. At minimum an empty list should be returned (never null).

member.name: T:Eamon.Framework.Delegates.RevealEmbeddedArtifactFunc
member.summary: Reveals an embedded artifact, moving it into its containing room and printing its description if necessary.
member.param: The room containing the embedded artifact.
member.remarks: If the artifact is embedded within the room, it is revealed; moved into the room's regular inventory list, and its description is printed if it hasn't been seen. While this task is typically performed during resolution of the direct or indirect object during player command parsing, you can reveal embedded artifacts at any appropriate point during the game by calling the method explicitly.

member.name: P:Eamon.Framework.IEngine.MacroFuncs
member.summary: A collection of functions used to resolve macros embedded in Desc and StateDesc properties for various record types.
member.remarks:
You can embed macros in the Desc or StateDesc properties of the various record types to produce dynamically generated strings for output during gameplay. Eamon CS supports the standard macros found in Eamon Deluxe, plus a new type based on lookups done in the MacroFuncs dictionary:
MacroResult
*XXXInjects [CRLF + CRLF + effect Uid XXX] into the property string (no brackets)
**XXXInjects [effect Uid XXX] into the property string
@XXXInjects [CRLF + CRLF + string returned by Func w/Key XXX] into the property string
@@XXXInjects [string returned by Func w/Key XXX] into the property string
The functions stored in MacroFuncs are typically lambdas but can be any valid function returning a string. This mechanism is incredibly powerful as it can exploit all facets of the game engine to calculate the string returned. Also, the dictionary can be manipulated during gameplay with old functions removed and/or new functions added if beneficial.
However, there are a few things to keep in mind. You can run EamonDD in a mode where it will display resolved macros; the option is called Resolve Effects and it exists off the CONFIG RECORD MENU. If you load the MacroFuncs dictionary during gameplay (typically in InitArtifacts or InitMonsters, but this isn't a requirement), EamonDD will NOT be able to resolve any function macro so it will remain. But there are scenarios where you can load MacroFuncs in such a way that functions are available to EamonDD, which will then use them to resolve macros. The upshot of this is that you should always write the functions installed in MacroFuncs in such a way that they are insensitive to whether they are being executed by EamonRT or EamonDD. The best way to do this is to be aggressive about checking for null at all times and return default strings when appropriate. There are many examples of macro functions written for the various Eamon CS adventures; the See Also list below is a good place to start.

member.name: P:Eamon.Framework.IEngine.Preps
member.summary: An array of sentence prepositions (eg, "to", "from", "inside", etc).
member.remarks: Other than to check the Length, you should never access this array directly; always use .

member.name: P:Eamon.Framework.IEngine.NumCacheItems
member.summary: Each record type has a quick-lookup cache in the database that stores this many items.
member.remarks: The database uses B-Plus Trees as the backing store, one tree and one quick-lookup cache per record type. Using a cache speeds up the record access times since the actual "search" on the tree is more like a full-table scan (this might get fixed at some point). This value is initialized using .

member.name: P:Eamon.Framework.IEngine.UnknownName
member.summary: A generic string representing an unknown name (eg, "???").
member.remarks: Typically the fallback value when a record with a given Uid is looked up for its Name property, but not found.

member.name: M:Eamon.Framework.IEngine.GetPreps(System.Int64)
member.summary: Gets the sentence preposition (eg, "to", "from", "inside", etc).

member.remarks: This method looks up and returns the preposition associated with a given index. It is a Getter method that can be overridden in a subclass to intercept array accesses or provide other specialized behavior. You must ensure the passed index is valid for the Preps array or an exception will be thrown.
member.returns: The preposition associated with a given index.

member.name: M:Eamon.Framework.IEngine.GetGameState
member.summary: Gets the IGameState record.
member.remarks:
This method returns a record of type ; there should be at most one of these in the database when running a game using EamonRT (or a derivative). Note that when running an EamonRT derivative the returned record may be cast to a derived IGameState defined in the derived game library, if any. There are many examples of this, one of which is . This allows you to easily access any game-specific methods or properties you've defined in your customized IGameState.
In other circumstances, this method will return null if no IGameState record is found in the database. When running EamonDD this record should never exist and thus null will always be returned.
member.returns: A record of type IGameState (or a game-specific subclass of it) or null.

member.name: M:Eamon.Framework.IEngine.GetModule
member.summary: Gets the IModule record.
member.remarks:
This method returns a record of type ; there should be at most one of these in the database when editing an adventure using EamonDD or running a game using EamonRT (or a derivative). Note that when running an EamonRT derivative the returned record may be cast to a derived IModule defined in the derived game library, if any (it would have been loaded out of the game's MODULE.XML file). This allows you to easily access any game-specific methods or properties you've defined in your customized IModule.
In other circumstances, this method will return null if no IModule record is found in the database. This can occur in EamonDD when an adventure is not being edited.
member.returns: A record of type IModule (or a game-specific subclass of it) or null.

member.name: M:Eamon.Framework.IEngine.RollDice(System.Int64,System.Int64,System.Int64,System.Int64@)
member.summary: Rolls a number of dice, returning a sum of the results.
member.param: An optional modifier to add to the sum; may be any value (including 0).
The summed result of the die rolls, plus the modifier (if any).
member.remarks: This is the dice-rolling function for Eamon CS. It rolls a number of dice, each with a given number of sides and sums the results. An optional modifier is then added in; this modifier may be negative, positive or zero. The common roleplaying game nomenclature would be to roll XdY+Z. While you can use this method directly, there is a convenience method that is recommended.
member.returns: Success, InvalidArg

member.name: M:Eamon.Framework.IEngine.RollDice01(System.Int64,System.Int64,System.Int64)
member.summary: Rolls a number of dice, returning a sum of the results.
member.param: An optional modifier to add to the sum; may be any value (including 0).
member.remarks: This is a convenience wrapper around which should be used whenever possible.
member.returns: The summed result of the die rolls, plus the modifier (if any).

member.name: M:Eamon.Framework.IEngine.SumHighestRolls(System.Int64[],System.Int64,System.Int64@)
member.summary: Given an array of die rolls, sum the highest of them and return the result.
member.param: The number of die rolls to sum.
The summed result of the highest die rolls.
member.remarks:
This method takes an array of die rolls, sorts the array in place from lowest to highest roll, then sums the requested number of rolls and returns the result.
It is intended to be used in conjunction with the method.
member.returns: Success, InvalidArg

member.name: M:Eamon.Framework.IEngine.UnlinkOnFailure
member.summary: Deletes a set of game-related files from the filesystem.
member.remarks:
This method is called by EamonRT during game startup if any of the following are true:
The Character record read from FRESHMEAT.XML is missing.
The Module record read from MODULE.XML is missing.
The Room record (where the game begins) read from ROOMS.XML is missing.
The above cases are considered fatal errors and this method is called to clean up the filesystem before the game aborts. The exact files deleted are EAMONCFG.XML, FRESHMEAT.XML and SAVEGAME.XML. These files are created during the transfer of the player into the adventure and are no longer needed once shutdown completes.

member.name: T:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.Armor
member.summary: An enumeration of character Armor Classes.
member.remarks: These armor classes parallel those found in Eamon Deluxe. You can take a look through the documentation for EDX or wait for the Eamon CS Dungeon Designer's Manual, which will have more details.

member.name: T:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.ArticleType
member.summary: An enumeration of Article Types.
member.remarks: These article types are applied to artifacts and monsters and improve the aesthetics of the output, making it more natural to read. You can modify any record at runtime to change its article type, if desired.

member.name: F:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.ArticleType.None
member.summary: No article is ever applied. For example, "Trollsfire" or "Heinrich".

member.name: F:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.ArticleType.A
member.summary: The name is preceded by "a". For example, "a flashlight" or "a wolverine".

member.name: F:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.ArticleType.An
member.summary: The name is preceded by "an". For example, "an axe" or "an orc".

member.name: F:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.ArticleType.Some
member.summary: The name is preceded by "some". For example, "some leather armor", "some silver cups" or "some green slime".
member.remarks: For artifacts, it is important to distinguish between singular artifacts (like the leather armor) and plural artifacts (the silver cups). Plural artifacts should be named as singular; this article type combined with the right plural type will produce the correct name. The situation for monsters is similar; it is important to distinguish between singular monsters (like the green slime) and group monsters. Group monsters have their own plural syntax (eg, "seven kobolds"). Group monsters should be named as singular, but with a singular article type (eg, "a kobold"), and the right plural type.

member.name: F:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.ArticleType.The
member.summary: The name is preceded by "the". For example, "the Rings of Xylo" or "the Emerald Warrior".
member.remarks: Typically only applied to unique artifacts or monsters, or those with special importance in the game.

member.name: T:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.ArtifactType
member.summary: An enumeration of Artifact Types.
member.remarks: These artifact types parallel those found in Eamon Deluxe, but Eamon CS supports a multiple artifact type paradigm. You can take a look through the documentation for EDX or wait for the Eamon CS Dungeon Designer's Manual, which will have more details.

member.name: T:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.Clothing
member.summary: An enumeration of Clothing Types.
member.remarks: These clothing types parallel those found in Eamon Deluxe. You can take a look through the documentation for EDX or wait for the Eamon CS Dungeon Designer's Manual, which will have more details.

member.name: T:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.CombatCode
member.summary: An enumeration of monster Combat Codes.
member.remarks: These represent the behavior of monsters while in combat. Their effect on gameplay is intended to parallel the Combat Code setting found in Eamon Deluxe.

member.name: F:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.CombatCode.NeverFights
member.summary: The monster will never fight.

member.name: F:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.CombatCode.NaturalWeapons
member.summary: The monster will favor weapons but fall back to natural weapons if necessary.

member.name: F:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.CombatCode.Weapons
member.summary: The monster will use either weapons or natural weapons (but never both).

member.name: F:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.CombatCode.Attacks
member.summary: The monster will be described as "attacking"; otherwise mirrors the Weapons setting.

member.name: T:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.Direction
member.summary: An enumeration of (compass) Directions.
member.remarks: These represent the possible directional links between rooms in a game. Each room contains an array that is indexed using these Direction values. The array will always be created assuming a 10-direction game; for 6-direction games, the last four (4) elements will be unused.

member.name: T:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.Friendliness
member.summary: An enumeration of monster friendliness values.
member.remarks: Each monster in a game has a reaction to the player character, as defined by this enum. This is pretty standard to Eamon in general and Eamon CS is no different.

member.name: F:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.Friendliness.Enemy
member.summary: The monster is hostile to the player character and all Friend monsters. The monster attacks on sight and flees the room or pursues based on courage.

member.name: F:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.Friendliness.Neutral
member.summary: The monster ignores all other monsters and refuses to flee the room, or attack either Friend or Enemy.

member.name: F:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.Friendliness.Friend
member.summary: The monster is friendly, follows the player character around and attacks Enemy monsters.

member.name: T:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.Gender
member.summary: An enumeration of character/monster genders.
member.remarks: Each character or monster in a game is assigned a gender value. For player characters this is of course set during creation in the Main Hall. As with all other properties, the gender value can be manipulated during gameplay (and, in at least one ECS adventure, actually is!)

member.name: F:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.Gender.Male
member.summary: The character or monster is male.

member.name: F:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.Gender.Female
member.summary: The character or monster is female.

member.name: F:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.Gender.Neutral
member.summary: The monster is neutral/indeterminate. Not available to player characters.

member.name: T:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.LightLevel
member.summary: An enumeration of room Light Levels.
member.remarks: These represent the possible ambient light levels found in rooms in a game. Each room has its own light level value which can be manipulated during gameplay if desired.

member.name: F:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.LightLevel.Dark
member.summary: Dark rooms are very restrictive on the kind of activities allowed.

member.name: F:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.LightLevel.Light
member.summary: Lit rooms allow the full range of commands.

member.name: T:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.PluralType
member.summary: An enumeration of Plural Types.
member.remarks: These plural types are applied to artifacts and monsters and improve the aesthetics of the output, making it more natural to read. You can modify any record at runtime to change its plural type, if desired. The plural type is only applicable to plural artifacts and group monsters, although if possible you should still assign the correct one even when it won't be used. If you have a special situation where none of the following values applies (eg, "Rings of Xylo"), customized plural names can be created using effects.

member.name: F:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.PluralType.None
member.summary: No plural type is ever applied. For example, "aircraft" or "moose".

member.name: F:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.PluralType.S
member.summary: The name is followed by "s". For example, "flashlights" or "wolverines".

member.name: F:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.PluralType.Es
member.summary: The name is followed by "es". For example, "crucifixes" or "finches".

member.name: F:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.PluralType.YIes
member.summary: The name ends with "y" - which is dropped - and is followed by "ies". For example, "factories" or "canaries".

member.name: T:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.RoomType
member.summary: An enumeration of Room Types.
member.remarks: These represent the possible types of rooms found in a game. Each room has its own room type value which can be manipulated during gameplay if desired.

member.name: F:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.RoomType.Indoors
member.summary: The room is considered indoors; the adjacent rooms list is prefixed with "Obvious exits".

member.name: F:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.RoomType.Outdoors
member.summary: The room is considered outdoors; the adjacent rooms list is prefixed with "Obvious paths".

member.name: T:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.Spell
member.summary: An enumeration of character Spells.
member.remarks: These spells should be familiar to anyone who has been involved with Eamon before. The Eamon CS Dungeon Designer's Manual will have more details.

member.name: T:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.Stat
member.summary: An enumeration of character Stats.
member.remarks: The last three should be familiar to anyone who has been involved with Eamon before; Intellect is unique to Eamon CS, and represents the character's mental capacity, wisdom and/or intelligence.

member.name: T:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.Status
member.summary: An enumeration of (character) Statuses.
member.remarks: These represent the possible states that a player character can be in. Each character has an associated Status that is set based on various game activities.

member.name: F:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.Status.Unknown
member.summary: The state of the character is indeterminate (in practice, this Status is unused).

member.name: F:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.Status.Alive
member.summary: The character is available for use; this is the default Status.

member.name: F:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.Status.Dead
member.summary: The character is not available for use; this is trivially reversible, however.

member.name: F:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.Status.Adventuring
member.summary: The character is out on an adventure.

member.name: T:Eamon.Framework.Primitive.Enums.Weapon
member.summary: An enumeration of character Weapon Skills.
member.remarks: These weapon skills should be familiar to anyone who has been involved with Eamon before. The Eamon CS Dungeon Designer's Manual will have more details.

member.remarks: This array contains the name for each member of . You should never access this array directly; always use the Getter methods mentioned below.

member.name: P:Eamon.Game.Engine.ClothingNames

member.remarks: This array contains the name for each member of . You should never access this array directly; always use the Getter methods mentioned below.

member.name: P:Eamon.Game.Engine.MacroFuncs
member.summary: A collection of functions used to resolve macros embedded in Desc and StateDesc properties for various record types.
member.remarks: There is a detailed writeup on this property in . As a general rule you should feel free to manipulate this dictionary at any point during gameplay, although typically it is only loaded during game startup. There are no Getter/Setter methods so all access is direct.

member.name: P:Eamon.Game.Engine.Preps
member.summary: An array containing sentence prepositions (eg, "to", "from", "inside", etc).
